CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: However , it seems that some larger phase aggregation occurs in PzNDTDTBT / PC71BM blend , which has a negative effect on the PSCs and corresponds to the slight photovoltaic performance degradation of PzNDTDTBT. 21a,26. Herein , the EQE curves of the devices with the optimal performance are shown in Figure 8. The devices showed a relatively high photoconversion efficiency over the whole wavelength range of 300-700 nm , with monochromatic EQE values around 50-60 % . Compared to the absorption spectra of pristine polymers , the significantly broadened EQE responses in the visible region can be attributed to both the intrinsic absorptions of the polymers and PC71BM. Also , it can be noted that devices based on PzNDTDTBO show stronger Field - Effect Transistor Properties. The performances of polymer field - effect transistors based on PzNDTDTBT and PzNDTDTBO were investigated using a bottom-gate , bottomcontact configuration. . ( Figure 9 ). All devices with L = 5 μm showed the highest hole mobility at different annealing temperatures. The devices showed a typical p - type transporting characteristic measured under ambient conditions. As shown in Table 4 , for both polymers the annealing temperature tends to affect the hole mobility. All devices based on both polymers were annealed at 60 , 100 , 140 , 180 , 220 , and 260 °C , and both polymers showed thermal stability on each device. Figure 10 shows the output curves and transfer characteristics of the OFETs based on the polymers at 25 °C and optimal annealing temperature. ( Other OFETs data at different annealing temperatures are shown in Supporting Information Figures S1 and S2. ) After thermal annealing , the hole mobilities of both copolymers are increased , which implies that the crystallinity of the polymer films and ordered lamellar structure of π-π closepacking for polymer main chain are significantly improved at higher temperatures. High current modulation is observed with on / off current ratio of 10^6 -10^7 for PzNDTBTBO while PzNDTDTBT shows relatively lower on / off ratio of 10^3 -10^4. The resulting optimal P-channel transistors demonstrate high hole mobilities of 0.43 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 for PzNDTDTBT and 0.34 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 for PzNDTBTBO. Both the hole mobilities are among the highest values for BT-or BO - based polymers. In order to deeply study the variation of the performances of OFETs of PzNDTDTBT and PzNDTDTBO after annealing , the thin - film microstructures and topographies were investigated by X-ray diffraction ( XRD ) and AFM. Figure 11 shows XRD patterns of the polymer thin films deposited on OTSmodified Si / SiO 2 substrates. For both polymers , obvious diffraction peaks were detected before the samples were annealed , which indicates that some degree of crystallinity has been formed at room temperature. PzNDTDTBT showed a sharp diffraction peak at 2θ = 21.4 ° and two weak peaks at 23.8 ° and 26.6 ° for the as-prepared thin film.

Let's think step by step.

Sure, I'd be happy to help you identify the "Material Name" entities in the paragraph!

1. "PzNDTDTBT" - This is a material name entity.
2. "PC71BM" - This is also a material name entity.
3. "PzNDTDTBO" - This is another material name entity.
4. "L" - This is not a material name entity, but rather a variable or parameter mentioned in the paragraph.
5. "Figure 8" - This is a reference to a figure in the text, but it is not a material name entity.
6. "Figure 9" - Same as above.
7. "Figure 10" - Same as above.
8. "Supporting Information Figures S1 and S2" - These are references to figures in the supporting information of the paper, but they are not material name entities.
9. "XRD" - This is an abbreviation for "X-ray diffraction," which is a technique used to study the crystal structure of materials. It is not a material name entity.
10. "AFM" - This is an abbreviation for "atomic force microscopy," which is a technique used to study the topography of materials. It is not a material name entity.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

Of course! Here are the material name entities in the paragraph:

1. "PzNDTDTBT"
2. "PC71BM"
3. "PzNDTDTBO"

I have removed the irrelevant entities from the list. Let me know if you have any other questions!

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Certainly! Here are the valid material name entities in the paragraph, presented in a Markdown table with one column titled "Material Name":

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PzNDTDTBT |
| PC71BM |
| PzNDTDTBO |

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.

Please identify the Property Names of materials in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: However , it seems that some larger phase aggregation occurs in PzNDTDTBT / PC71BM blend , which has a negative effect on the PSCs and corresponds to the slight photovoltaic performance degradation of PzNDTDTBT. 21a,26. Herein , the EQE curves of the devices with the optimal performance are shown in Figure 8. The devices showed a relatively high photoconversion efficiency over the whole wavelength range of 300-700 nm , with monochromatic EQE values around 50-60 % . Compared to the absorption spectra of pristine polymers , the significantly broadened EQE responses in the visible region can be attributed to both the intrinsic absorptions of the polymers and PC71BM. Also , it can be noted that devices based on PzNDTDTBO show stronger Field - Effect Transistor Properties. The performances of polymer field - effect transistors based on PzNDTDTBT and PzNDTDTBO were investigated using a bottom-gate , bottomcontact configuration. . ( Figure 9 ). All devices with L = 5 μm showed the highest hole mobility at different annealing temperatures. The devices showed a typical p - type transporting characteristic measured under ambient conditions. As shown in Table 4 , for both polymers the annealing temperature tends to affect the hole mobility. All devices based on both polymers were annealed at 60 , 100 , 140 , 180 , 220 , and 260 °C , and both polymers showed thermal stability on each device. Figure 10 shows the output curves and transfer characteristics of the OFETs based on the polymers at 25 °C and optimal annealing temperature. ( Other OFETs data at different annealing temperatures are shown in Supporting Information Figures S1 and S2. ) After thermal annealing , the hole mobilities of both copolymers are increased , which implies that the crystallinity of the polymer films and ordered lamellar structure of π-π closepacking for polymer main chain are significantly improved at higher temperatures. High current modulation is observed with on / off current ratio of 10^6 -10^7 for PzNDTBTBO while PzNDTDTBT shows relatively lower on / off ratio of 10^3 -10^4. The resulting optimal P-channel transistors demonstrate high hole mobilities of 0.43 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 for PzNDTDTBT and 0.34 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 for PzNDTBTBO. Both the hole mobilities are among the highest values for BT-or BO - based polymers. In order to deeply study the variation of the performances of OFETs of PzNDTDTBT and PzNDTDTBO after annealing , the thin - film microstructures and topographies were investigated by X-ray diffraction ( XRD ) and AFM. Figure 11 shows XRD patterns of the polymer thin films deposited on OTSmodified Si / SiO 2 substrates. For both polymers , obvious diffraction peaks were detected before the samples were annealed , which indicates that some degree of crystallinity has been formed at room temperature. PzNDTDTBT showed a sharp diffraction peak at 2θ = 21.4 ° and two weak peaks at 23.8 ° and 26.6 ° for the as-prepared thin film.

Let's think step by step.

Sure, I'd be happy to help you identify the property names of materials mentioned in the paragraph! Here are the materials mentioned in the paragraph along with their property names:

1. PzNDTDTBT - Polymer
2. PC71BM - Material
3. PzNDTDTBO - Polymer
4. L - Length (of the device)
5. T - Temperature (annealing temperature)
6. EQE - External Quantum Efficiency
7. Field - Effect Transistor Properties
8. Hole mobility - A measure of the speed of charge carriers (holes) in a material
9. p-type transporting characteristic - A type of transport mechanism in a material
10. OFETs - Organic Field-Effect Transistors
11. BT - Butylene terephthalate
12. BO - Butylene ortho-phthalate
13. XRD - X-ray Diffraction
14. AFM - Atomic Force Microscopy

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any further questions.

Also , it can be noted that devices based on PzNDTDTBO show stronger Field - Effect Transistor Properties. The performances of polymer field - effect transistors based on PzNDTDTBT and PzNDTDTBO were investigated using a bottom-gate , bottomcontact configuration. . ( Figure 9 ). As shown in Table 4 , for both polymers the annealing temperature tends to affect the hole mobility. 1. EQE (Equivalent Circuit Element) values:

2. Hole mobility:
 * Hole mobility of PzNDTDTBT: 0.43 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 (mentioned in the paragraph)
 * Hole mobility of PzNDTBTBO: 0.34 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 (mentioned in the paragraph)
3. Absorption spectra:
 * Absorption spectra of pristine polymers: not mentioned in the paragraph
4. Thermal stability:
 * Annealing temperature affects the hole mobility of both polymers (mentioned in the paragraph)
 * Devices based on both polymers were annealed at various temperatures (mentioned in the paragraph)
5. Field-Effect Transistor (FET) properties:
 * PzNDTDTBT and PzNDTDTBO showed stronger FET properties (mentioned in the paragraph)
 * Hole mobility of devices based on PzNDTDTBT and PzNDTBTBO were investigated using a bottom-gate, bottom-contact configuration (mentioned in the paragraph)
